Revision – Genitiv with Complex Sentences

Let's translate these to review all concepts so far:
1. We play with our father's watch
2. My father's car comes with your mother's car
3. He comes without his child's ball

Answers – Genitiv Revision

Remember: Genitiv is always easier if you ignore the 'whose' part first and make the simple sentence, then add the possessor (Tour de France rule).

1. Main: We play with the watch.
Add Genitiv: Wir spielen mit der Uhr unseres Vaters.

2. Main: My father's car comes with your mother's car.
Das Auto meines Vaters kommt mit dem Auto deiner Mutter.

3. Main: He comes without the ball.
Add Genitiv: Er kommt ohne den Ball seines Kindes.

Imperativ – Commands in German

We've learned how to make polite requests. Now, we learn how to give commands.
Formal commands (Sie-form) are just like polite requests:

  • Kommen Sie hier! (Come here!)
  • Essen Sie Pasta!
  • Trinken Sie Tee!

Informal Commands – du/ihr

For du-commands (informal, to one person), take the 'du' form and remove the ending -st:

  • Trink Tee! (Drink tea!)
  • Lern Deutsch! (Learn German!)
  • Komm hier! (Come here!)
  • Hilf mir! (Help me!)
  • Koch Pizza! (Cook pizza!)

Irregular Verbs – Imperativ

Some verbs change in the du-form. If the verb stem itself changes, only remove the 't' or 'st' ending:

  • Lies Harry Potter! (Read Harry Potter!)
  • Iss Pizza! (Eat pizza!)
Don't remove 's' if part of the original verb stem.

German Commands: Rude to Most Polite

  • Trink Tee! (most direct)
  • Trinken Sie Tee!
  • Trinken Sie Tee, bitte!
  • Können Sie Tee trinken?
  • Könnten Sie Tee trinken? (could you – most polite)

Summary

  • Formal command: 'Sie' form + verb (Trinken Sie Tee!)
  • Informal du-command: remove -st ending (Trink Tee!)
  • For irregular verbs, watch for changes in the stem.
  • Politeness: Direct command < others < with 'bitte' < 'können/könnten' forms.
  • With Genitiv: Build the simple sentence first, then add the possessor after the object (Tour de France rule).
